headline: The Procter & Gamble Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess I wanted to ask sort of broadly about your thoughts on this acquisition of dollar shave, but more sort of openly, how do you think about digital and social reducing cost of competition in categories where Procter has historically dominated? Or how
componenttext: I guess I wanted to ask sort of broadly about your thoughts on this acquisition of dollar shave, but more sort of openly, how do you think about digital and social reducing cost of competition in categories where Procter has historically dominated? Or how do you think about vulnerability of the business broadly in sort of specific areas?

headline: The Procter & Gamble Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of comments. The digital and social space, to me, is a powerful opportunity for any consumer marketing company, and it's left all of us to figure out how to best leverage the capability that has been developed, and frankly, for consumers to
componenttext: Just a couple of comments. The digital and social space, to me, is a powerful opportunity for any consumer marketing company, and it's left all of us to figure out how to best leverage the capability that has been developed, and frankly, for consumers to emerge rapidly. P&G has shifted significantly its resources and our investments to ensure that we are showing up with communication that wins mobile back. And that's a big shift for us. And that's critically important because whether it's e-commerce or whether it's consumption of media, in many markets, it's now primarily through the mobile phone. And more and more, you're seeing P&G winning with the marketing programs that are adapted for digital and social. And a good example of one of a social program that has done extraordinarily well is the Always Like A Girl where we leverage that communication in that very strong social platform, but used and leverage the social media capability to drive the brand. I do understand, and certainly there's very real cost to enter a category has changed dramatically today versus 5 and 10 years ago. And part of what we are doing, by category [indiscernible] is looking to see how we leverage liquidity that exist. Expect will continue to see competitors that can up. But generally, to sustain and grow a business, you have to have a product and a product experience that meets the consumers' need. There are many, many examples of Internet-based competitors that have been popping up both here and China. Tremendous number of those. You get trial, repurchase those another story. And we purchase in a profitable business model is the highest bar. And that's the one that we're working against. We just have a substantive product that meets the consumers need, communication programs that meet consumers, receptive to the message and understand they want less to be solved and more to be part of their life. And we're adjusting our marketing communication programs to do just that. I think that's the right way by category to win.

headline: The Procter & Gamble Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from the line of Jonathan Feeney with Consumer Edge Research.
componenttext: Next question comes from the line of Jonathan Feeney with Consumer Edge Research.

headline: The Procter & Gamble Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to follow up on that a little bit about e-commerce probably picked up about social media, digital media as opportunities. But e-commerce, clearly, the Chinese consumers seems to have skipped a generation as far as how they're behaving with e-c
componenttext: I just want to follow up on that a little bit about e-commerce probably picked up about social media, digital media as opportunities. But e-commerce, clearly, the Chinese consumers seems to have skipped a generation as far as how they're behaving with e-commerce and it -- I think it's one of your major competitors up to, like, 13% or 14% of their business in China. I wonder, it seems like a lot of your other categories are susceptible, not just through vehicles like Dollar Shave Club, but to e-commerce probably, regular but not awfully frequent purchase, not really impulses, not really impulse purchases, managing households and inventories. Two, a more comprehensive e-commerce strategy that could really get you ahead. I mean, do you have any thoughts about that? Could you talk about specifically about e-commerce opportunities in outside of China, in big developed markets for maybe there are more -- there's more upside to come?

headline: The Procter & Gamble Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, sure. One, actually think e-commerce is growing in most of our markets. If I look at the top 8 e-commerce markets for us in the world, it would be U.S., China, U.K., Germany, Japan, Korea, France and India. On 6 of those 8, now growing share on e-co
componenttext: Sure, sure. One, actually think e-commerce is growing in most of our markets. If I look at the top 8 e-commerce markets for us in the world, it would be U.S., China, U.K., Germany, Japan, Korea, France and India. On 6 of those 8, now growing share on e-commerce and it's because we have adjusted significant they do not see it as a separate activity, but an integrated part of our we go and meet consumers when and where they're receptive to shop. Our growth rate is -- varies between kind of 1 10 up to the highest market we currently have is 1 85. And the size of our business, you mentioned China, some of our competitors have quoted more than 10%. We're well above 10% of our business is on e-commerce and growing fast. And past 6 months, were up 0.7 share in e-commerce in Greater China -- our in China, specifically. So yes, it is growing. We have established efforts in each of the major markets where there's a meaningful part of our business. We now have 5, 6 categories where it's over a $100 million business and growing fast. And again, in general, we're at market growth or a little bit higher on majority of our markets, the top 8 markets. And then look at the lens of customers, we're working very closely with any of the customers, would it be bricks and mortars, channel players or the pure plays, to make sure that we have the portfolio and the communication that wins with them and whether it is the [indiscernible] retailers in the U.S. or around the world or whether it's the pure plays on Amazon, or Alibaba, both we're trying to ensure that we show up having consumer and shopper data that helps develop the category and that we have the product offerings to win. And again, our results, the last 6 months, to me, speak to the pivot we've made to make sure we show up in that segment very, very well. And the last comment I'd make is we also ensuring that we adjust our packaging and our sizing to ensure we have the right [indiscernible] to what with consumers and shoppers want to shop in the channel again looking for each category wins.

headline: The Procter & Gamble Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Ali Dibadj with Bernstein.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Ali Dibadj with Bernstein.

headline: The Procter & Gamble Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I want to go back a little bit to price mix versus volume and sort of its implications for the industry overall, please. Because, look, overall in the quarter, clearly price mix was lower than, I think, expected. It's certainly lower than peers, given
componenttext: So I want to go back a little bit to price mix versus volume and sort of its implications for the industry overall, please. Because, look, overall in the quarter, clearly price mix was lower than, I think, expected. It's certainly lower than peers, given especially currency movements, inflation, et cetera but [indiscernible] came a little bit higher. Even if you didn't have FX issues in North America, think, Jon, you said volumes up 3, sales up only 2. And you said that that's the pattern we should expect going forward. So leading more volumes than price mix overall. Trying to figure out what that suggest about the competitive environment we should expect in the HBC as you execute your turnaround plans? I mean, if you think about 2017, obviously [indiscernible] mid-single-digit EPS growth so there's not a lot of EPS growth beyond Coty and Duracell. Every -- all of the cost savings you're talking about, the top line growth can be reinvested in the bottom line. It's going to be reinvested into the market. So it feels like you're planning to win by outspending your competitors massively, where it sounds like it might be a little tough in HBC right now and perhaps not sustainable longer term even for you guys. So love some help on figuring out what I'm missing on that because it sounds a little frightening right now.

headline: The Procter & Gamble Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll start there, Ali. I'll let David chime in. If you look at price inclusive of promotion as a component of top line, we've been neutral to positive for 23 straight quarters and 12 consecutive years. And I don't think that relative preference in the dri
componenttext: I'll start there, Ali. I'll let David chime in. If you look at price inclusive of promotion as a component of top line, we've been neutral to positive for 23 straight quarters and 12 consecutive years. And I don't think that relative preference in the drivers for business growth changes going forward. But we've had 2 dynamics that we've been dealing within the last year that kind of inform next year's view. One is we've been pricing significantly to recover foreign exchange impacts, which has resulted in volume being less of a component of the top line. In fact, in many cases, a negative component. We are hopeful that we're going to be operating in more stable currency environment. So that volume negative goes away. Also, as you have and others have rightly pointed out on several occasions, we've had category-country combinations where our pricing got too high. In many cases, that's what we were trying to recover from devaluation and competitors didn't follow. In other cases, David talked about [indiscernible] in his prepared a major competitor pricing down in that segment and will be adjusting prices to deal with those realities, which makes price less of the top line component and volume more of it. We have no interest in spending unproductively. Our intent is to drive, as David said, category growth. And we do not see the business in most parts of the world through a 0-sum lens in any way.

headline: The Procter & Gamble Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll add [indiscernible] make is a completely agree that the lens that we're looking at category. We can do innovation and brand building, both of which are taking investments to grow the category both for the short, mid and long term. We have not yet com
componenttext: I'll add [indiscernible] make is a completely agree that the lens that we're looking at category. We can do innovation and brand building, both of which are taking investments to grow the category both for the short, mid and long term. We have not yet completed entirely and annualize the value investments that need to be made. It's been most acute in places like Russia where the differential impact we had was very severe for U.S. domiciled companies. And you've seen even Russia volume share has recovered. And until we analyze that, it will show up with the dynamic that you highlighted. But there, our front half was below 100 and our back half is double-digit. And especially the fourth quarter. That will annualize, and we get back to exactly what Jon said, which is our business model is very, very clear, which is we want to invest in innovation and brand building, especially focused the brand building and bringing consumers in and then we want to delight them so they stay with our brand. And the spending is heavily focused there other than some selective value interventions, almost all driven by foreign exchange and the category settling out to a place where we're back in an acceptable price corridor and where we get into the end of that.

headline: The Procter & Gamble Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would just add one last piece of perspective many of us have discussed this previously, but we're we have a choice to spend $1 on innovation, on brand building, building our equities or on promotion, I think David and I would both spend that $1 every da
componenttext: I would just add one last piece of perspective many of us have discussed this previously, but we're we have a choice to spend $1 on innovation, on brand building, building our equities or on promotion, I think David and I would both spend that $1 every day on the first 2 items. And the reason is very simple. There is nothing proprietary in promotion. It doesn't build sustainable advantage where the other forms of spending can when we get them right. So I've just offered that as a reminder to how we think about the operations of the business.

headline: The Procter & Gamble Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Kevin Grundy with Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Kevin Grundy with Jefferies.

headline: The Procter & Gamble Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So question, David, on competitive dynamics in North America, but specifically, 2 notable transactions you announced. You touched a little bit on the Dollar Shave dynamic with Unilever. I want to ask that a bit differently. Specifically, are you anticipat
componenttext: So question, David, on competitive dynamics in North America, but specifically, 2 notable transactions you announced. You touched a little bit on the Dollar Shave dynamic with Unilever. I want to ask that a bit differently. Specifically, are you anticipating greater investment there? It would certainly seem like given the scale that Unilever brings that that would be a reasonable expectation. Is that yours? Is that contemplated in the guidance? And then also, if you could comment on Henkel's acquisition of Sun? And specifically there, what's your expectation? And do you see a more conducive setup for pricing rationality now in U.S. liquid? Because we've seen episodic price worse through the years there, but now we're at a level of industry consolidation that should lend itself to greater pricing rationality.

headline: The Procter & Gamble Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, the Dollar Shave plan and Unilever's acquisition of Dollar Shave Club. We have, already this year, increased our support for our U.S. Shave Care business, and we'll continue to make sure we support it at the level required to get back to growing. T
componenttext: First, the Dollar Shave plan and Unilever's acquisition of Dollar Shave Club. We have, already this year, increased our support for our U.S. Shave Care business, and we'll continue to make sure we support it at the level required to get back to growing. The strategic choice to make that are highlighted earlier, which is very important and should play a positively in spite of Unilever's acquisition of Dollar Shave club, is activating more than just the high end of the portfolio, where we're most vulnerable is at the mid and lower tier. And if you look at our share losses, that's where we get most acute. And Dollar Shave club is come in with, in some cases, a lower absolute cash outlay. Not a better-performing products, and actually not a better-value product, when you look over time. And for that reason, we have -- and we had challenges which I think are well known in private label and disposables. So we've gone back and innovate in all 3 tiers and also addressed and now funded marketing programs to be developed and disposables, the Mach3 segment both in innovation and brand supported in the premium tier. To me, that will continue to be funded. That is anticipated in our guidance. That's part of the base plan for fiscal '17 for Shave Care. Moving to the second one on Fabric Care. Henkel's acquisition of Sun. We're aware. There's a lot of concern to go back a year ago, with [indiscernible] when it came in that would have a real detrimental impact on our business. And the view we took then is the same we take now, is that there will be dynamics in the marketplace that could change. And we'll see how the category sorts itself out. But the -- we're able to win is the same strategy going into fiscal '17. Fabric Care focused on consumers and shoppers. They brought aggressive innovation to make sure that their meeting the shoppers' needs better than anybody else, premium performing products. And they did a great job communicating in sampling their products. This fiscal year built into our guidance is increased level sampling and with a broader sampling program as well as the marketing program that is in place, and I've just mentioned some additional innovation coming on the product front, I think we're actually well positioned, and the objective going in independent of what happens in terms of industry consolidation is that we will win with consumers and shoppers. We'll see how that plays out on the other point.

headline: The Procter & Gamble Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

headline: The Procter & Gamble Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Question on -- have to go a little deeper on China, please. You get maybe 5 or 6 major categories. Just looking at diapers, Olay, specifically and hair, could you talk about what product innovations -- what level of product innovation you see coming? Any
componenttext: Question on -- have to go a little deeper on China, please. You get maybe 5 or 6 major categories. Just looking at diapers, Olay, specifically and hair, could you talk about what product innovations -- what level of product innovation you see coming? Any sort of granularity would be helpful. Because it seems and diapers, the Japanese are discounting their products and there's a big shift in where things are bought. In Olay, we just haven't heard a lot recently. And in hair, I think you still got issues with your biggest brand there. So that would be helpful.

headline: The Procter & Gamble Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Certainly. I'll take each and turn. On all 3, yes, there are innovation -- important innovations coming in fiscal '17. Some of them have not been announced. So I won't get into any specifics. Diapers, we know we got behind on diapers. It shows up in its o
componenttext: Certainly. I'll take each and turn. On all 3, yes, there are innovation -- important innovations coming in fiscal '17. Some of them have not been announced. So I won't get into any specifics. Diapers, we know we got behind on diapers. It shows up in its one of the most acute categories in terms of share loss. Period. The category is very -- understand in the categories we focus on winning in China. We -- 6, 9 months ago, made a choice that we're going to win in China and then allocated the resources and the capital to ensure that we had the appropriate product innovation coming. It's not yet publicly announced some of these major innovations are coming. But on both diapers and pants very committed to it. An encouraging sign to me about the future in China is to look at what we've been able to do recently in Japan. We're in Japan, you seen is now take the share leadership. And frankly, we're losing to primarily Japanese competitors have done well China, as well as Casey. And innovation we have coming over the next fiscal year and beyond, we think will position us well. On Olay, our first step was to get our portfolio cleaned up. That's been done. If you step back and look at the 4 core collections on Olay, we're starting to see a meaningful difference, which is to become a very positive sign and that's Total effects, Regenerist, segment [indiscernible] On those, we see back half doing better than second half. We still have to anniversary some of the discontinued SKUs. In the second key innovation on Olay will be getting our [indiscernible]  Been to China many times in previously [indiscernible] in greater China. Our counters of that [indiscernible] that have not been upgraded recently. So we've shut down the counters that the earn stores that are productive. And we've made meaningful investments in upgrading the counters in the stores that we think have a basis -- places are basis to compete. Account innovation it's coming. It's already happening. It is funded. And it's so it's up now. Innovations are becoming on primarily the 4 core collections and then some new innovations that will be doing. In the last category, is hair largest category, in China, we have meaningful innovations coming on on both the conditioner, and it's the peer [indiscernible] earlier. It's all of the loss in the U.S. and loss in China. And the superior-perform. We have key innovation coming in many of our brands, Pantene and Head & Shoulders, historically have been stronger. Actually growing share and got innovation coming on in Rejoice, which is been the weakest of our brands in China. So on each one of the brands, focus. We've also made the choice funded and staffed on the ground resources to ensure we keep up with the pace of innovation required in the Beauty segment. This to me is, is an important choice about winning in the future in China. Thank you.
